dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news out of Japan today, uh, about the Tokyo Olympics. It looks like, you know, overseas spectators won't be able to attend the games.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news out of Japan today, uh, about the Tokyo Olympics. It looks like, you know, overseas spectators won't be able to attend the games.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, that's gotta be a huge bummer for a lot of people. I mean, they've been waiting for this for like, a year now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, that's gotta be a huge bummer for a lot of people. I mean, they've been waiting for this for like, a year now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 2020 Games were postponed by a year due to the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The organizing committee, um, made the call, basically saying it's to help ease concerns about seeding COVID-19 outbreaks there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. The organizing committee, um, made the call, basically saying it's to help ease concerns about seeding C O V I D-nineteen outbreaks there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, safety first. But I heard a ton of tickets were already sold, like, hundreds of thousands?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, safety first. But I heard a ton of tickets were already sold, like, hundreds of thousands?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the organizers, approximately 600,000 tickets were sold overseas...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, officially around 600,000, but some reports say it's closer to a million. The good news is, uh, they *are* covering cancellation fees for flights and accommodations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, officially around six hundred thousand, but some reports say it's closer to a million. The good news is, uh, they are covering cancellation fees for flights and accommodations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee asserted that refunds for tickets would be issued, but Tokyo 2020 Chief Executive Officer Toshiro Muto said cancellation fees related to airline travel and accommodations previously booked would not be covered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Okay, that's something at least. So people aren't just out all that money, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that's something at least. So people aren't just out all that money, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it sounds like this decision was made pretty independently by the Tokyo committee, not really with the national government or the IOC.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it sounds like this decision was made pretty independently by the Tokyo committee, not really with the national government or the I O C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee made the decision jointly with national and local governments in Japan and the International Olympic and Paralympic Committees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting. So, like, what's the general vibe in Japan? Are people even excited about it at this point?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting. So, like, what's the general vibe in Japan? Are people even excited about it at this point?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You know, it's mixed, but surprisingly, a lot of Japanese citizens actually *do* want the games to go ahead. A recent survey said about 80% don't want another postponement or cancellation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, it's mixed, but surprisingly, a lot of Japanese citizens actually do want the games to go ahead. A recent survey said about eighty percent don't want another postponement or cancellation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 80% of Japanese believe the games, which are scheduled to begin in July, should be postponed again or canceled altogether, according to a survey by national broadcaster NHK.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, really? Even with, like, the COVID situation and everything?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, really? Even with, like, the C O V I D situation and everything?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I guess it's a sense of moving forward. But, um, they still haven't decided on capacity limits for domestic spectators yet. That's coming next month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I guess it's a sense of moving forward. But, um, they still haven't decided on capacity limits for domestic spectators yet. That's coming next month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Muto said a determination on capacity limits at venues for domestic spectators would be made before the end of next month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's still TBD how many people from Japan will actually be in the stadiums, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's still T B D how many people from Japan will actually be in the stadiums, then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Meanwhile, the torch relay actually kicks off this Thursday in Fukushima. That's going to be a four-month journey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Meanwhile, the torch relay actually kicks off this Thursday in Fukushima. That's going to be a four-month journey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The torch relay for the games will begin Thursday in Fukushima Prefecture and will last four months, with roughly 10,000 runners traversing the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's a nice touch, a little bit of normalcy. I did see something about Tokyo's state of emergency, though? I thought they were trying to lift it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's a nice touch, a little bit of normalcy. I did see something about Tokyo's state of emergency, though? I thought they were trying to lift it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They were. Prime Minister Suga wanted to, but, uh, an advisory panel rejected that plan just this week. So, still under it for now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They were. Prime Minister Suga wanted to, but, uh, an advisory panel rejected that plan just this week. So, still under it for now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Thursday, the Japanese government's advisory panel on coronavirus countermeasures approved the plan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Man, it sounds like it's just one thing after another for these games. But hey, at least they're pushing through, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man, it sounds like it's just one thing after another for these games. But hey, at least they're pushing through, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They are, like, full steam ahead. It's definitely going to be an Olympics unlike any other, that's for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They are, like, full steam ahead. It's definitely going to be an Olympics unlike any other, that's for sure.
